Some of the smallest daito tsuba that I am aware of are found on a few of the well-known Tensho period katana koshirae.

For the earlier question about katana vs. wakizashi tsuba sizes see the "Katana Koshirae" .xls or .doc files on the group site:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/files/

Jim



  With number four Matt I think you are closest to the truth,
        A large tsuba is a hindrance for a mounted archer, encounters 
  on horseback were rarely "tsuba to tsuba" therefore a handgaurd if it 
  ever was one was unnecessary. A handstop on the other hand was of 
  absolute necessity...
  -t
